The course focuses on the colonial history of North America, from 1491 up to 1763. As a student, you will learn about the social, political, legal, and economic development of the American continent under various iterations of European rule. You are a witness to the dramatic changes on the continent that such colonization efforts brought about. The course describes the rise of indentured servitude and then the institution of slavery from the 16th to 18th centuries. The course is taught without any essential reference to the American revolution of 1776; this is a course about the empires and states that preceded the American experiment, which only comes in the late 18th and early 19th centuries. You'll get a great feel for colonial life as it affected the everyman, and explore the intricacies of colonial conflict and development, including religious life, ethnic diversity, and commerce within and without the British empire.

Strengths: Professor Peterson, the material, lectures, section. Pretty much everything this is an amazing course. We also had the unique advantage of the course being very small, which I think had to do with the fact that Professor Peterson was new and didn't have any course evals (Yalies are super risk averse when it comes to course selection). This meant that Professor Peterson ended up needing to lead our section, since another course with higher enrollment poached his TF. He was super available when it came to our papers, in a way that would've been impossible with a larger class. I hope more people take this class in the future it's amazing  but the small enrollment was a great surprise bonus.
Weaknesses: Not much. The reading that was assigned was A LOT, and it would've been pretty impossible to read all of it for the detail required for section Towards the middle of the course, Professor Peterson started sending emails letting us know what to focus on for that week, which was really helpful. We were also assigned a few books that we didn't end up using  understandable, as the class had never been taught before and I'd imagine Professor Peterson was changing some things along the way, but I'd hope this will be cleared up in the future. Section was sometimes more of a second lecture than a discussion, which was okay  Peterson is so engaging  but perhaps something to know going in.

The course's strength is its focus: you will get a thorough and detailed understanding of colonial life, culture, and society from the 16th to the 18th centuries. This is also an indubitably important part of global history: we see the rise of the first true empires, and the formation of European-dominated societies in the New World. The subject is well explored in the scholarship, and it is an important one to explore, as a student. The course is excellent as is; the primary source materials are engaging, and lectures supplement them quite well. Discussion sections could benefit from a greater degree of multilateralism. The way to elicit reluctant students' input is an understandable challenge, however, and is certainly not unique to this course.

Yes, I would recommend this course to any student who is interested in premodern American history. It provides a well crafted and engaging story of how empires and states operated on the American continent prior to the age of revolutions. If you enjoy American history before the United States, or are interested in studying it, this course gives a great opportunity to do so. Don't take this course if you are interested in learning much about the United States itself. If you're interested in the British Empire, slavery, or Native American studies, this is a great course. People interested in religious and commercial history from the 15th to the 18th centuries will also find much to enjoy in the course.
